reviewText: This little known movie stars Tom Selleck as an American jewel cat thief in pre-World War II London. It's a great movie and has an incredible supporting cast including Bob Hoskins as a police officer doggedly on the title characters trail. Adding beauty to the movie is former Bond girl Jane Seymour as Selleck's girlfriend and the impossibly sexy Lauren Hutton as a Nazi.With OTT Nazi's as the villains this movie truly is a great ride and a DVD release is long overdue.There is a DVD available in Europe (Region 2) for those of us with region-free players.
summary: An overlooked gem of a movie

reviewText: This is one of Tom's best movies! He's great as the suave, notorious jewel thief! Jane Seymour is gorgeous, Lauren Hutton isvery intriguing as the sexy Nazi Agent & Bob Hoskins makes a really irritating policeman! Filmed on location in London,the WWII setting is interesting! A fabulous ending! This is a real keeper! I love this film!Price was reasonable & it was delivered quickly!
summary: Very Well Done Film With Surprising Twist at the End!

reviewText: At last, here is an excellent DVD transfer of a very underrated but excellent movie. I previously imported the Spanish DVD release, and the quality was poor. It looked like a VHS enhanced transfer.HEN"S TOOTH video has released a very "handsome" DVD, with very professional packaging. The picture quality is extremely close to the theatrical prints I used to project as a part-time projectionist in college. The aspect ratio is nicely framed as an anamorphic 1.85:1. The soundtrack is very good, not excellent, and probably from a MONO source, but processed as 2-track stereo. There are no extras, other than English subtitles.I hope the Blu-ray of this little gem of a movie is coming soon, because, I would buy it in that format again. I recommend this disc as the best available for this title.
summary: LASSITER is as rare as Hen's teeth!

reviewText: Bought this along with "High Road to China" - two of my favorite Tom Selleck movies which finally came out on DVD/Blu-ray this year.  Even knowing all the twists and turns, this is still a lot of fun to watch.  Selleck plays a cat burgler in typical Magnum fashion.  Great to see Bob Hoskins again in his role as a bad/good cop.  Quality of the DVD is OK - could be better, but really didn't take away from the movie.  Grab the popcorn, sit back and enjoy the show!

reviewText: LASSITER is a movie about a jewel thief in London during the years just before World War II. After an arrest he is pressured by British law enforcement and the FBI into attempting to steal a horde of gems from the German Embassy.The film is a fairly entertaining romp but there are problems with the script and some of the actors seem to be miscast. The movie does have many excellent sets and Tom Selleck gives a strong performance as Lassiter. The supporting cast includes Jane Seymour, Laura Hutton and Bob Hoskins. Hoskins is particularly good in the role of Inspector John Becker.

reviewText: This is an early Tom Selleck film, done about the time he was doing Magnum P.I.  It's a period piece set in the days just before the beginning of WW II, and it is well written and the acting by Tom was his absolute best.  Tom plays a high-end jewel thief who gets recruited by the british government and the America's FBI to steal some jewels from the German consulate in Britian, which the Germans plan to use towards their upcoming War effort. It has a great cast that includes Jane Seymour, Laren Hutton, and Bob Hoskins just to mention a few.  This is the first time that this movie has been offered on DVD (something I have been waiting for, for years)and I hope it is followed up by a blu-ray version like they did with Tom Selleck's "High Road to China" which was also shot in about the same time period as "Lassiter" and another great period piece that Tom did.  I highly recommend this film,especially if you are a Tom Selleck fan like I am, I promise you won't be dissappointed with it.
summary: Early Tom Selleck at his Absolute Best
Title: N/A

reviewText: In this 1983 film, Nick Lassiter (Tom Selleck) is a super slick, always charming, cat burglar/second story man.  The setting is England, June,1939, just before the German invasion in Europe.  Lassiter has been framed by  inspector Becker (Bob Hoskins) of the London police, in order to force him to steal 10 million in diamonds from a secret vault in the German Embassy.  Jane Seymour is his beautiful but jealous girl friend. Mari (Lauren Hutton) is the alluring but deadly german countess charged with the safe keeping of the diamonds. Her faithful body guard, Max is even more deadly.  There is some brief nudity which might offend the sensitive types, but I think it's tastefully done.This is a fast paced action adventure movie.  The outcome is predictable but will still keep you interested throughout.  All the actors play interesting and believable roles.  The memorable musical score adds to the 30's flavor of the film.I did own a VHS copy but decided to buy the DVD when it came out, because I loved watching it so much.  If you saw and liked "High Road to China", also starring Tom Selleck, I think you will like this one too.

reviewText: I don't remember where I first saw 'Lassiter', but I almost always see a movie on TV or at the theater before I buy a copy for my personal library.  I'm glad to see this finally out on DVD - and with subtitles for the hearing impaired.The storyline might seem a little corny - blackmailing a known cat burglar to steal diamonds from a foreign embassy to disrupt Nazi operations in South America.  But when you consider that during World War II British Intelligence actually dressed a dead body as a British officer and floated it onshore in Spain with phony letters suggesting the Allied invasion of southern Europe would be through Greece (instead of Sicily), and it worked . . . well, who knows.  (It was known as operation Mincemeat.)What I liked about this movie was the set designs.  They were so 1930s!  Set designers don't get the credit they should.  I particularly like the scenes at the nightclubs and on the train.  And they had the cars right, also.  Good set designs add a lot to any movie.The chemistry between Tom Selleck and Jane Seymour was good.  And Bob Hoskins was great as the 'copper'.  If there was a disappointment in the acting, it was Joe Regalbuto as the FBI agent.  He came across as a wimp, and FBI agents just are not timid.  But I would be remiss if I did not give credit to Lauren Hutton, who played a Nazi courier with a wild side.So when you put the acting and set designs together with the plot, you come up with a movie that's pretty entertaining.  Enjoy.
